Description: Corroded copper alloy aegis with a head of Bastet lioness wearing a tripartite headdress, topped by sun-disc with uraeus, and a semi-circular gorget plate, with stepped upper edge. A vertical suspension ring is welded at the back of the sun-disc, on top of the head. The menat-counterweight is made of a large vertical strip of metal, bent at the top, fastened to the backside top of the gorget, under the headdress, by a pair of small vertical rings interlocked with an oval one, and stuck by corrosion. Slightly narrowing downwards, flanked by opposed uraei, the lower part of the counterweight ends with a disc.
Curator's comments: One of three "Aegis of Bast", the one "with handle" mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 80 § 80, pl. xxxix.4.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 80 § 80, pl. xxxix, 4)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.44, p.56, p.177, pl.19)
